publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. correction on p. 3, unsigned and undated. 9p. Wanting p. 1. Paginated 2-10.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Anon.
common voice singing out of doors. he has no house. He lives

a roaming life, crossing the fields,
moutning mounting the hills,

and lying down by the hawthown to listen to
te the nightingale.

Still, by shutting out a
chimey chimney or a bungalow
we can see what Anon saw-- the bird haunted reed whispering
fen, the down, and the green scar never healed along which

he came when he made his journeys. He was a
simp le simple singer,

lifting a song or a story from other peoples lips, and
lettig letting

the
auience audience join in the
chours chorus . Sometimes he made a few

lines that exactly
matchedhis matched his
emtoin emotion --he was an
arist artist .
But there is no name to that song.

When at last the house was built, he
song sung only at the
back door. Upstairs they spoke French; his song was sung
in English; and the words were so uncouth

that they
n ed need a
ditioc nary dictionary now.

Bu But to the listener then, to Harrison for
xample example in his
pasronage parsonage , they were not only difficult. They were painful.
They reminded him of his lack of intellectual

His intellectual pedigree reached
vack back only to Gower

Langland, Chaucer, a bare
hundre hundred and fifty years.

To have
anscestors ancestors he must
ross cross the channel. His ancestors

by way of the mind are Greeks and
Rla ns Romans . His page is

bu dened burdened with
protesttaions protestations
og of good breeding--
enricus Henricus

Conrnilus Cornelius Agrippa; Suetonius , Pliny;
Civero Cicero --xxxxxxx
ixx quotes them to prove his good breeding as we to prove

ours quote the
Elizabthans Elizabethans .

Anon was not a
respecable respectable ancestor. He was nameless

because he was
disrputable disreputable . Even the Kings and Queens must

have their
sin ers singers , their
mistrels minstrels , their xxxxxxx actors.
But he was despised. Did he not feeling himself an outcast,

use the outsiders privilege of
irreponsible irresponsible mockery?
Hewas tolerated, as we tolerate those who say out loud
what we think, but will not admit. So hesang, danced

uggled juggled and led his bears to the back
doot door . He sings to
serving men and maids. He tells them what they have heard

aldready already --old stories in
inm hose in those choruses they can join.
When the great Elizabethan house was built, he was still

nameless,
disreptuable disreputable , ????? Harrison the
prason parson of Radwinter

in Essex instead of setting down those
ongs songs , digs up

coins. He already
s s sees the present against the past.

The past has become so settled that
yhe the present looks

ngainly ungainly and
d g n rate degenerate against it. There is too much

comfort, too many
pi ows pillows , too many chimneys. The young
Sahkespeares Shakespeares and marlowes are not the men their fathers were.

The
msmoke smoke drawn up by the
chimeys chimneys no
lo ger longer hardens them.
They are tender and subject to rheumatism. They dress

fantatically fantastically compared with their
ancestor.s ancestors. It does not
occur to him to set down the songs that were being sung, to

describe the
pagentatns , pageants, the
mu ming mumming , the plays that the

wandering
mistrels minstrels enacted. The English past served only to

show the material change-- the change
tha that had come over

houses,
furinture furniture
clothing½ clothing There was no English literature
to show up the change in the mind. There were no English
boo s books to show up the decline of English writing.

Up stairs in the great room , as
Ha ison Harrison tells us,

"...our ancient ladies of the
co rt court "
we e were to be found reading

the
Gekks Greeks and Latins as they sat at their
needlwork needlework .
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx Greek and Latin
came as easily to their pens as English. At Gorhambury

isnatnec instance Lady
An Anne Bacon sat writing to her son. Her letters
might have been sermons from the pulpit. Shxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx She
exhorst exhorted ; she
admonsihed admonished .

Fear of God,
suspcion suspicion of man surround her with the walls
of a dungeon. There is no gaiety, no familiarity, no intimacy

in this world.
hw She
draoes drapes herself in the
langauge language of the
B le Bible
when she writes; and it is a garment only to fit a certain

attitude. Save for Chaucer and
Langdale Langland and the voice of

Anon singing at the back door, making his
irrevent irreverent mockeries
xmxmxmxmxmx the English might be a dumb race; a race of

merchants
soliders soldiers priests, who left
ehind behind them stone houses
cultivated fields and many churches, but no words. The

great house is
sielnt silent . We can see it still,
satnding standing in its

green island of park,
seaparated separated often from the high road,
only by a dip in the ground and a low red wall. It is out

village with its
bungalwos bungalows and shops is too small. The
furn furniture

is in
exsitnce existence too. Inside all is kept as if the Queen were
expected. The up right Elizabethan chairs stand round the

walls. Their fringes and their
tap st y tapestry is not much faded

The oak tables are heavy and polished. The floor is
str wn strewn
